title: 2 Samuel Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 16.

questions.question: Who met King David with provisions when he was a little past the top of the hill?
options: Ziba
Shimei
Abishai
Hushai
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:1 states that Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, met David with provisions.

questions.question: What did Ziba say the bread and summer fruit were for?
options: For the young men to eat
For the king's household
For Absalom's army
For the priests
questions.correctAnswer: For the young men to eat
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 16:2, Ziba says the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat.

questions.question: Where was Mephibosheth's son said to be staying according to Ziba?
options: Jerusalem
Bahurim
Hebron
Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:3 records Ziba saying Mephibosheth's son remains in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What did King David give to Ziba after hearing his report?
options: All that pertained to Mephibosheth
A place in his army
A royal crown
The city of Bahurim
questions.correctAnswer: All that pertained to Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 16:4, David gave Ziba everything that belonged to Mephibosheth.

questions.question: Who cursed King David as he came to Bahurim?
options: Shimei
Ahithophel
Abishai
Hushai
questions.correctAnswer: Shimei
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:5 tells us a man named Shimei of Saul's family came out and cursed David.

questions.question: What did Shimei do to King David besides cursing him?
options: Cast stones and dust at him
Bowed and gave gifts
Sang praises
Offered him food
questions.correctAnswer: Cast stones and dust at him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:6 and 2 Samuel 16:13 describe Shimei casting stones and dust at David.

questions.question: What reason did David give for letting Shimei curse him?
options: Because the LORD has told him to
Because he was afraid
Because Shimei was a friend
Because he was weak
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD has told him to
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 16:10, David says the LORD has told Shimei to curse him, so he lets him.

questions.question: Who asked David for permission to kill Shimei?
options: Abishai
Ahithophel
Hushai
Ziba
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:9 shows Abishai asking David to allow him to kill Shimei.

questions.question: What did David hope the LORD would do regarding Shimei's cursing?
options: Look on his affliction and requite him good
Punish Shimei immediately
Make Shimei his servant
Send Shimei away
questions.correctAnswer: Look on his affliction and requite him good
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:12 expresses David's hope that the LORD will reward him for Shimei's cursing.

questions.question: Who came to Jerusalem with Absalom?
options: Ahithophel
Ziba
Shimei
Abishai
questions.correctAnswer: Ahithophel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:15 states that Absalom and all Israel's men came to Jerusalem with Ahithophel.

questions.question: True or False: Hushai told Absalom that he would serve whichever side the LORD and Israel chose.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:18 records Hushai telling Absalom he will serve whomever the LORD and Israel choose.

questions.question: True or False: Absalom asked Hushai why he did not go with his friend David.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 16:17, Absalom questions Hushai about not going with David.

questions.question: True or False: Ahithophel's counsel was considered as if one had consulted the oracle of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:23 states that Ahithophel's counsel was as if one had inquired of God directly.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Samuel 16:21: 'Go in unto thy father's ______, which he hath left to keep the house.'
options: concubines
servants
friends
enemies
questions.correctAnswer: concubines
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:21 says Ahithophel advised Absalom to go into his father's concubines.

questions.question: What did Absalom do after receiving Ahithophel's counsel?
options: Went in unto his father's concubines
Fled the city
Called for a feast
Sent Hushai away
questions.correctAnswer: Went in unto his father's concubines
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 16:22 describes Absalom spreading a tent and going into his father's concubines as advised.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 2 Samuel 16, what biblical truth would you share about responding to personal attacks and insults?
options: We should seek revenge immediately to defend our honor.
We should ignore insults and let God handle the situation.
We should curse back to show strength.
We should withdraw from people who insult us.
questions.correctAnswer: We should ignore insults and let God handle the situation.
questions.explanation: David allowed Shimei to curse him and did not retaliate because he recognized the Lord had permitted it (2 Samuel 16:7-10). This teaches trusting God in adversity rather than seeking personal revenge.

questions.question: How does David’s interaction with Ziba (2 Samuel 16) teach us about integrity and discernment in difficult times?
options: David blindly trusted Ziba without question.
David gave Ziba all of Mephibosheth’s property based on Ziba's word.
David immediately punished Ziba for lying.
David ignored Ziba’s report completely.
questions.correctAnswer: David gave Ziba all of Mephibosheth’s property based on Ziba's word.
questions.explanation: David accepted Ziba’s explanation and granted him Mephibosheth’s possessions (2 Samuel 16:3-4), but this shows the challenge of making decisions in trials and the need for wisdom and prayer in discerning truth.

questions.question: What does David’s response to Abishai’s suggestion to kill Shimei reveal about humility and submission to God’s will?
options: David welcomed Abishai’s plan to kill immediately.
David ignored Abishai and cursed Shimei himself.
David refused to harm Shimei, submitting to God’s plan.
David ordered his men to capture Shimei.
questions.correctAnswer: David refused to harm Shimei, submitting to God’s plan.
questions.explanation: David said to let Shimei curse because the Lord had told him so (2 Samuel 16:9-10), showing humility and submission to God’s sovereign will in trials.

questions.question: A believer struggles with trusting God during difficult family conflict. What can 2 Samuel 16 teach about perseverance through such trials?
options: Fight against family members to regain control.
Trust that God may bring good from the affliction and persevere.
Avoid family completely to prevent conflict.
Seek revenge to protect your rights.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God may bring good from the affliction and persevere.
questions.explanation: David hoped the Lord would look on his affliction and repay good for the cursing he endured (2 Samuel 16:11-12), demonstrating faith and perseverance in family trials.

questions.question: How does Hushai’s conduct towards Absalom teach us about loyalty and serving God's will in church or fellowship life?
options: Hushai immediately betrayed David to Absalom.
Hushai declared loyalty to God’s chosen leader and served accordingly.
Hushai refused to serve anyone.
Hushai only served Absalom for personal gain.
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai declared loyalty to God’s chosen leader and served accordingly.
questions.explanation: Hushai told Absalom he would serve whichever leader the Lord and the people chose (2 Samuel 16:17-19), showing submission to God’s authority and faithfulness in service.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity and stewardship can be learned from Ziba’s provision for David and his men?
options: Ziba provided supplies for selfish reasons only.
Ziba showed generosity by bringing food and drink for the weary.
Ziba refused to help David.
Ziba demanded payment for his assistance.
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba showed generosity by bringing food and drink for the weary.
questions.explanation: Ziba met David with bread, fruit, and wine to refresh him and his men (2 Samuel 16:1-2), illustrating practical generosity and service to others.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 16, David retaliated immediately when Shimei threw stones at him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David did not retaliate but allowed Shimei to curse and throw stones, trusting God’s judgment (2 Samuel 16:5-8, 13).

questions.question: True or False: Ahithophel’s counsel to Absalom was considered as wise as an oracle from God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ahithophel’s advice was highly respected and described as if one inquired at the oracle of God (2 Samuel 16:23), indicating the importance of godly counsel.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When Absalom wanted to strengthen his position, Ahithophel advised him to ______.
options: go in unto his father's concubines
attack David immediately
make peace with David
leave Jerusalem quietly
questions.correctAnswer: go in unto his father's concubines
questions.explanation: Ahithophel advised Absalom to go to his father's concubines publicly to show he was abhorred by his father and strengthen his followers (2 Samuel 16:21-22).

questions.question: How does David’s response to Shimei’s cursing teach about forgiveness and love for neighbors amidst trials?
options: David sought to kill Shimei to stop the cursing.
David accepted the cursing without retaliation, showing patience.
David cursed Shimei back in anger.
David ignored the cursing and walked away silently.
questions.correctAnswer: David accepted the cursing without retaliation, showing patience.
questions.explanation: David allowed Shimei to curse him and refrained from responding in kind (2 Samuel 16:7-12), exemplifying forgiveness and love even to enemies.

questions.question: A believer faces false accusations that threaten their reputation. What biblical principle does David’s experience with Ziba and Mephibosheth teach about handling such situations?
options: Take the accusations personally and retaliate immediately.
Make decisions with faith and leave ultimate justice to God.
Ignore all advice and act on impulse.
Publicly shame the accuser.
questions.correctAnswer: Make decisions with faith and leave ultimate justice to God.
questions.explanation: David accepted Ziba's report but did not rush judgment against Mephibosheth, showing the need for faith and patience in handling accusations (2 Samuel 16:3-4).

questions.question: What can we learn about spiritual discipline and prayer through David’s conduct when facing opposition from his own son, Absalom?
options: David gave in to despair and fled without hope.
David continued trusting God and sought His will amid the betrayal.
David tried to negotiate with Absalom immediately.
David gathered his men for a violent attack.
questions.correctAnswer: David continued trusting God and sought His will amid the betrayal.
questions.explanation: David endured Absalom’s rebellion with faith, trusting God’s ultimate plan (implied through the narrative in 2 Samuel 16:15-23), teaching spiritual discipline in trials.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the importance of humility and contentment during times of hardship?
options: David’s acceptance of hardship without fighting shows humility and contentment.
David demanded immediate restoration of his kingdom.
David ignored his servants and went alone.
David cursed his enemies in return.
questions.correctAnswer: David’s acceptance of hardship without fighting shows humility and contentment.
questions.explanation: David endured insults and loss humbly, refusing to retaliate and trusting God (2 Samuel 16:7-12), demonstrating contentment in trials.

questions.question: What lesson about serving others and generosity can be learned from the way David and his men were refreshed during their journey?
options: David refused all help to demonstrate independence.
Ziba’s provision illustrates practical generosity and care for others’ needs.
David only accepted help from nobles.
David’s men went hungry and thirsty.
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba’s provision illustrates practical generosity and care for others’ needs.
questions.explanation: Ziba brought bread, fruit, and wine to refresh David and his men (2 Samuel 16:1-2, 14), showing the blessing of serving and generosity.

questions.question: What does Hushai’s response to Absalom teach about faithfulness in leadership and relationships?
options: Hushai remained loyal to David and served Absalom only as God’s will directed.
Hushai immediately betrayed David for personal gain.
Hushai refused to serve anyone.
Hushai fled the country.
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai remained loyal to David and served Absalom only as God’s will directed.
questions.explanation: Hushai declared he would serve whoever the Lord and people chose, showing faithfulness and submission to God’s authority (2 Samuel 16:17-19).

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 16.

questions.question: What does Ziba bring to King David as he passes the top of the hill?
options: Two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred bunches of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a bottle of wine
A sword and a shield for battle
Gold and silver for the king's treasury
A message of peace from Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred bunches of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a bottle of wine
questions.explanation: Ziba met David with asses saddled carrying two hundred loaves, a hundred bunches of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a bottle of wine as provisions (2 Samuel 16:1).

questions.question: What reason does Ziba give for Mephibosheth's absence from David?
options: Mephibosheth stays in Jerusalem because he expects the kingdom to be restored to him
He was sent as a spy to Absalom
He was captured by the enemies of David
He fled to a foreign land for safety
questions.correctAnswer: Mephibosheth stays in Jerusalem because he expects the kingdom to be restored to him
questions.explanation: Ziba explains that Mephibosheth remains in Jerusalem, expecting the house of Israel to restore his father's kingdom (2 Samuel 16:3).

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Shimei' in the context of his actions against David?
options: Shimei's name is associated with cursing and reflects his role as a vocal opponent of David
Shimei was a loyal soldier disguised to test David
Shimei is a title meaning 'peaceful one' used ironically
Shimei was the priest who cursed David
questions.correctAnswer: Shimei's name is associated with cursing and reflects his role as a vocal opponent of David
questions.explanation: Shimei, known for his curses, comes from the house of Saul and vocally curses David as he passes (2 Samuel 16:5-7), highlighting his opposition and the deep division within Israel.

questions.question: How does David respond to Abishai's request to kill Shimei?
options: David refuses and says the LORD has told Shimei to curse him
David orders Abishai to kill Shimei immediately
David ignores Abishai's request
David punishes Shimei but spares his life
questions.correctAnswer: David refuses and says the LORD has told Shimei to curse him
questions.explanation: David tells Abishai to leave Shimei alone because the LORD has instructed him to allow the curses, showing David’s submission to God's will (2 Samuel 16:10).

questions.question: What literary device is present in the interaction between David and Shimei regarding the curses?
options: A chiastic structure illustrating divine justice and human agency
An allegory comparing David to a shepherd
A metaphor for the exile of Israel
A parable about forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: A chiastic structure illustrating divine justice and human agency
questions.explanation: The passage uses chiasm by balancing Shimei's curses with David's acceptance, highlighting the tension between divine justice and human actions (2 Samuel 16:5-13).

questions.question: How does the historical context of ancient Near Eastern royal succession relate to Absalom's actions in this chapter?
options: Absalom publicly asserts his claim by taking his father's concubines, a symbolic act of seizing power
Absalom sends gifts to foreign kings to secure alliances
Absalom gathers an army to attack a neighboring nation
Absalom seeks priestly endorsement for his kingship
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom publicly asserts his claim by taking his father's concubines, a symbolic act of seizing power
questions.explanation: Absalom's act of taking his father’s concubines publicly symbolizes his claim to the throne, reflecting ancient Near Eastern customs of power assertion (2 Samuel 16:21-22).

questions.question: What role does Hushai play after joining Absalom in Jerusalem?
options: He pretends loyalty to Absalom while secretly supporting David
He advises Absalom to kill David immediately
He becomes Absalom’s military commander
He returns to David immediately with intelligence
questions.correctAnswer: He pretends loyalty to Absalom while secretly supporting David
questions.explanation: Hushai declares loyalty to Absalom to serve as a spy and counter Ahithophel’s counsel, demonstrating political intrigue (2 Samuel 16:16-19).

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the theological theme present in David’s acceptance of Shimei’s curses?
options: Divine sovereignty over human affairs
Human triumph over adversity
Retributive justice without mercy
Absolute royal authority
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty over human affairs
questions.explanation: David submits to God’s sovereign will by allowing Shimei to curse him, reflecting trust in divine control over events (2 Samuel 16:10-12).

questions.question: How does the counsel of Ahithophel function literarily within this chapter and the broader narrative?
options: As an oracle-like voice representing wisdom and impending doom
As a comic relief to tension
As a symbol of divine deliverance
As a minor subplot unrelated to the main story
questions.correctAnswer: As an oracle-like voice representing wisdom and impending doom
questions.explanation: Ahithophel’s counsel is described as if one inquired of God, lending gravity and foreshadowing disaster (2 Samuel 16:23).

questions.question: What is the significance of the Hebrew term translated as 'man of Belial' used by Shimei when cursing David?
options: 'Belial' denotes worthlessness and wickedness, emphasizing David's perceived guilt
'Belial' is a term of endearment
'Belial' means 'king' in Hebrew
'Belial' refers to a foreign god worshipped by Saul’s house
questions.correctAnswer: 'Belial' denotes worthlessness and wickedness, emphasizing David's perceived guilt
questions.explanation: The term 'Belial' connotes wickedness or worthlessness, used by Shimei to accuse David of bloodguilt and moral failure (2 Samuel 16:7).

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 16, Abishai was allowed by David to kill Shimei after he cursed the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David explicitly forbids Abishai from killing Shimei, stating that the LORD told Shimei to curse him (2 Samuel 16:9-10).

questions.question: Which thematic parallel can be drawn between David's experience with Shimei and later New Testament teachings?
options: Enduring unjust suffering and blessing those who curse you
Seeking revenge against enemies
Maintaining political power at all costs
Avoiding conflict through compromise
questions.correctAnswer: Enduring unjust suffering and blessing those who curse you
questions.explanation: David’s acceptance of curses aligns with New Testament teachings on blessing persecutors and enduring suffering patiently (2 Samuel 16:12; Romans 12:14).

questions.question: What is the significance of Absalom’s consultation with Ahithophel in the broader narrative of 2 Samuel?
options: It marks the turning point where Absalom gains strategic counsel for his rebellion
It shows Absalom’s lack of political acumen
It serves as a reconciliation moment between father and son
It introduces a foreign alliance
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the turning point where Absalom gains strategic counsel for his rebellion
questions.explanation: The consultation signals Absalom’s serious challenge to David’s reign, with Ahithophel’s advice lending credibility and danger (2 Samuel 16:20-23).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David said, "My son, which came forth of my bowels, seeketh my life: how much more now may this ______ do it?"
options: Benjamite
Levite
Foreigner
Philistine
questions.correctAnswer: Benjamite
questions.explanation: David refers to Shimei as a Benjamite, emphasizing tribal enmity and his greater threat compared to his own son Absalom (2 Samuel 16:11).

questions.question: What does the presence of summer fruits, raisins, and wine in Ziba’s provisions suggest about the cultural practices of hospitality and sustenance in the ancient Near East?
options: They represent typical portable provisions for travelers in hot, arid regions
They were luxury items only for royalty
They indicate a ritual sacrifice
They were used primarily for trade
questions.correctAnswer: They represent typical portable provisions for travelers in hot, arid regions
questions.explanation: These foods and drinks symbolize hospitality and nourishment appropriate for desert travel, reflecting ancient Near Eastern customs (2 Samuel 16:1-2).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Ziba's purpose in bringing provisions to King David as he fled?
options: To supply the king's household and the young men with food and drink
To betray David by withholding supplies
To enlist David's men for battle
To announce Absalom's rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: To supply the king's household and the young men with food and drink
questions.explanation: Ziba brought bread, fruit, and wine for David's household and young men to eat and drink during their wilderness journey, as stated in 2 Samuel 16:1-2. This act demonstrates God's providence and care for His servant in times of trial (cf. Exodus 16:4; Psalm 23:1-4; Matthew 6:25-34; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: How did David respond when he learned Mephibosheth was not with him?
options: He allowed Ziba to keep all of Mephibosheth's property
He sent men to bring Mephibosheth to him immediately
He accused Mephibosheth of treason
He punished Ziba for lying
questions.correctAnswer: He allowed Ziba to keep all of Mephibosheth's property
questions.explanation: David gave all that belonged to Mephibosheth to Ziba after hearing that Mephibosheth stayed in Jerusalem, trusting God's justice in the situation (2 Samuel 16:3-4). This reflects David's reliance on divine sovereignty and his willingness to endure personal loss, consistent with biblical teaching on trusting God in injustice (cf. Psalm 37:1-6; Romans 12:17-21; 1 Peter 2:19-23; Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: Who was Shimei and what did he do to King David?
options: A man from Saul’s family who cursed and threw stones at David
A loyal servant who helped David escape
A prophet who encouraged David
A commander who betrayed David
questions.correctAnswer: A man from Saul’s family who cursed and threw stones at David
questions.explanation: Shimei, of Saul's family, cursed David and threw stones at him as David fled from Absalom (2 Samuel 16:5-6). This episode illustrates the consequences of sin and divine judgment as well as the humility and patience David displayed under persecution (cf. Genesis 50:20; Matthew 5:44; Romans 12:14; 1 Peter 2:23; Psalm 69:9).

questions.question: What theological significance can be drawn from David’s refusal to retaliate against Shimei's curses?
options: David acknowledged that the Lord permitted the curses for a divine purpose
David feared Shimei’s power
David did not hear the curses
David was unsure of how to respond
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledged that the Lord permitted the curses for a divine purpose
questions.explanation: David understood that God had allowed Shimei to curse him for a purpose, exemplifying submission to God's sovereignty even in suffering (2 Samuel 16:10-12). This aligns with biblical teaching on God's control over evil and suffering for the believer's growth (cf. Job 1:21-22; Romans 8:28; 2 Corinthians 12:7-10; Hebrews 12:5-11; 1 Peter 4:12-19).

questions.question: What role did Abishai play in response to Shimei's actions?
options: He wanted to kill Shimei to defend the king's honor
He advised David to ignore Shimei
He joined Shimei in cursing David
He fled from the scene
questions.correctAnswer: He wanted to kill Shimei to defend the king's honor
questions.explanation: Abishai, David's warrior, sought to kill Shimei for cursing the king (2 Samuel 16:9), reflecting the human impulse for vengeance and defense of the king's dignity, which David restrained by trusting God's judgment (cf. Deuteronomy 32:35; Romans 12:19; 1 Samuel 24:10-11; Proverbs 20:22; Matthew 5:39).

questions.question: What was the significance of Absalom going into his father's concubines according to Ahithophel's counsel?
options: It was a public act to demonstrate Absalom's claim to the throne
It was a private act of grief
It was a way to reconcile with David
It was to protect the concubines
questions.correctAnswer: It was a public act to demonstrate Absalom's claim to the throne
questions.explanation: Ahithophel advised Absalom to publicly go into David's concubines to signal his rejection by his father and to strengthen his own position, a political act of usurpation (2 Samuel 16:21-22). This event highlights themes of rebellion, covenant violation, and the consequences of sin (cf. Genesis 49:4; 2 Kings 9:30; 1 Kings 2:13-25; Jeremiah 22:30; Ezekiel 16:37).

questions.question: How is Ahithophel’s counsel described in relation to divine guidance?
options: As if a man had enquired at the oracle of God
As foolish and misguided advice
As a secret plot unknown to others
As advice rejected by Absalom
questions.correctAnswer: As if a man had enquired at the oracle of God
questions.explanation: Ahithophel’s counsel was so wise and authoritative that it was likened to seeking God’s oracle, indicating the danger and seriousness of his advice (2 Samuel 16:23). This underscores biblical teaching on the importance of godly wisdom and the tragic consequences when such wisdom is used for evil (cf. Proverbs 3:5-7; 1 Kings 22:19-23; Jeremiah 27:9; James 1:5; Colossians 1:9).

questions.question: What does Hushai’s declaration to Absalom reveal about his loyalty and theological stance?
options: He professed loyalty to the Lord’s chosen king, whether David or Absalom
He openly opposed David’s kingship
He sought to betray Absalom immediately
He refused to serve any king
questions.correctAnswer: He professed loyalty to the Lord’s chosen king, whether David or Absalom
questions.explanation: Hushai stated he would serve whomever the Lord and Israel chose, demonstrating submission to God’s sovereign will and the principle of respecting God’s ordained authority (2 Samuel 16:17-19). This reflects biblical theology on divine election and human obedience to rightful rulers (cf. Romans 13:1-7; 1 Samuel 15:22; Proverbs 21:1; Daniel 2:21; Titus 3:1).

questions.question: What does the episode of David’s flight and Absalom’s rebellion teach about human sin and divine sovereignty?
options: Human sin leads to chaos, but God remains sovereign over the outcome
God abandons sinners who rebel
Sin always results in immediate judgment without delay
God’s sovereignty means human choices are irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: Human sin leads to chaos, but God remains sovereign over the outcome
questions.explanation: David’s flight because of Absalom’s rebellion shows the destructive consequences of sin and rebellion, yet God’s providence is evident in His control over events (cf. 2 Samuel 16:1-23; Genesis 50:20; Isaiah 46:9-11; Romans 8:28; Psalm 33:10-11). The chapter illustrates the tension between human responsibility and divine sovereignty.

questions.question: How does David’s treatment of Shimei reflect New Testament teaching on suffering and forgiveness?
options: David’s patience exemplifies Christ-like forgiveness and endurance
David’s acceptance of cursing encourages passivity in sin
David retaliated harshly, opposing forgiveness
David ignored God's will in the situation
questions.correctAnswer: David’s patience exemplifies Christ-like forgiveness and endurance
questions.explanation: David’s refusal to retaliate and his trust in God’s justice (2 Samuel 16:10-12) prefigure Christ’s teaching on loving enemies and suffering unjustly (cf. Matthew 5:44; Romans 12:14-21; 1 Peter 2:21-23; Luke 23:34; Hebrews 12:2). This models the Christian ethic of forgiveness and reliance on divine justice.

questions.question: In what way does the narrative of Absalom’s rebellion correspond to the biblical theme of the Messianic King?
options: It contrasts the faithful king David with the rebellious son, pointing forward to Christ
It endorses rebellion against God’s chosen leaders
It shows that kingship is irrelevant to God’s plan
It denies David’s legitimacy as king
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts the faithful king David with the rebellious son, pointing forward to Christ
questions.explanation: Absalom’s rebellion against David highlights the theme of the Messianic King who is faithful despite betrayal and opposition, foreshadowing Christ’s rejection by His own (cf. Psalm 2; Isaiah 53; John 18:36-37; Hebrews 12:2; Revelation 19:16). The chapter illustrates the conflict between divine kingship and human rebellion.

questions.question: What does God’s permission of Shimei’s cursing indicate about His justice and human agency?
options: God sovereignly permits certain actions for His purposes while holding humans accountable
God causes sin directly
Humans have no role in their actions
God is indifferent to human behavior
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly permits certain actions for His purposes while holding humans accountable
questions.explanation: David’s statement that the Lord has told Shimei to curse him (2 Samuel 16:10) shows that God allows events within His sovereign plan, yet humans remain responsible for sin (cf. Genesis 50:20; Acts 2:23; Romans 8:28; James 1:13-15; Ezekiel 18:20). This balances divine sovereignty with human responsibility.

questions.question: How does the provision of food and wine by Ziba relate to God’s provision for His people in wilderness situations?
options: It symbolizes God’s continued care for His people during trials
It was an act of selfishness by Ziba
It was a tactic to deceive David
It had no spiritual significance
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s continued care for His people during trials
questions.explanation: Ziba’s provision (2 Samuel 16:1-2) echoes God’s historical provision for Israel in the wilderness (Exodus 16:4,35) and points to Christ as the bread of life sustaining His people (John 6:35). It illustrates God’s faithfulness even in difficult times (cf. Psalm 34:10; Isaiah 58:11; Matthew 4:4; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: What ecclesiological lesson can be drawn from Hushai’s strategy in Absalom’s court?
options: Faithful witness within a hostile environment is crucial for God's purposes
One should always openly oppose evil rulers
It is better to abandon the community in times of crisis
Political allegiance is more important than spiritual loyalty
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful witness within a hostile environment is crucial for God's purposes
questions.explanation: Hushai’s infiltration of Absalom’s court (2 Samuel 16:16-19) demonstrates the importance of faithful presence and witness within adverse contexts, reflecting the New Testament call for believers to be salt and light in the world (cf. Matthew 5:13-16; Acts 9:15-16; Philippians 1:12-14; 1 Corinthians 9:22; 2 Timothy 2:3-7).

questions.question: What does the cursing and stoning of David by Shimei teach about the nature of sin and human opposition to God's anointed?
options: Sin often manifests as hostility toward God's chosen leaders
Sin always results in immediate repentance
God’s anointed are never opposed
Opposition to God’s servants is always righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Sin often manifests as hostility toward God's chosen leaders
questions.explanation: Shimei’s actions (2 Samuel 16:5-8) show how sin breeds rebellion against God’s purposes through opposition to His anointed, a theme continued in the rejection of Christ (cf. Psalm 2:1-3; Luke 19:14; John 15:18-20; Acts 4:26-28; Hebrews 13:7). This illustrates the cosmic conflict between good and evil.

questions.question: How does David’s experience in this chapter foreshadow Christ’s sufferings?
options: Both endured unjust accusations, rejection by their own, and relied on God’s justice
David was victorious without suffering
David retaliated violently against his enemies
David’s experience is unrelated to Christ’s
questions.correctAnswer: Both endured unjust accusations, rejection by their own, and relied on God’s justice
questions.explanation: David’s unjust treatment, rejection by Absalom and others, and his trust in God’s vindication (2 Samuel 16) prefigure Christ’s suffering, rejection by His people, and reliance on the Father (cf. Isaiah 53; Matthew 27:12-14; 1 Peter 2:21-24; Hebrews 12:2; Romans 8:32). This chapter enriches Christological understanding of the suffering servant.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about God’s justice is emphasized through the events of 2 Samuel 16?
options: God’s justice is perfect and will ultimately vindicate His servants
God ignores injustice in the world
God punishes without cause
God’s justice is arbitrary
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice is perfect and will ultimately vindicate His servants
questions.explanation: David’s patient endurance of injustice and his hope that God will repay good for evil (2 Samuel 16:12) affirm the biblical doctrine that God’s justice is perfect and will ultimately vindicate His people (cf. Psalm 37:28; Romans 12:19; Revelation 6:10; Ecclesiastes 12:14; Psalm 9:7-8). This encourages believers to trust God amid suffering.
